# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is how you could define the function `audi_filter`:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter data for Audi and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df = filter(r -> r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model in ["a4", "a4 quattro"]), df)

    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals true for all rows
    df[:, :audi_a4_type] = CategoricalArray(fill(true, size(df)[1]))

    return df
end
```

Here is how you can use this function with your given DataFrame:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

After running this code, `df_cars` will contain all rows from the original DataFrame where `manufacturer == "audi"` and `model == "a4"` or `"a4 quattro"`, along with a new boolean column named `audi_a4_type` which is `true` for all those rows.
